channel.title: kaggle on Ayush Subedi
channel.description: Recent content in kaggle on Ayush Subedi

item.title: Ames Housing Prediction
item.description:
Housing Prices Competition

Ask a home buyer to describe their dream house, and they probably won’t begin with the height of the basement ceiling or the proximity to an east-west railroad. But this playground competition’s dataset proves that much more influences price negotiations than the number of bedrooms or a white-picket fence.

With 79 explanatory variables describing (almost) every aspect of residential homes in Ames, Iowa, this competition challenges you to predict the final price of each home.

Base Model

Imports

import numpy as np 
import pandas as pd 
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestRegressor
from xgboost import XGBRegressor
from sklearn.model_selection import cross_val_score
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
from sklearn.compose import ColumnTransformer
from sklearn.pipeline import Pipeline
from sklearn.impute import SimpleImputer
from sklearn.preprocessing import LabelEncoder
from sklearn.metrics import mean_absolute_error

Read the training dataset and list its shape and column names

df = pd.read_csv('../data/AmesHousing/train.csv')
print (df.shape)
print (df.columns)

(1460, 81)
Index(['Id', 'MSSubClass', 'MSZoning', 'LotFrontage', 'LotArea', 'Street',
       'Alley', 'LotShape', 'LandContour', 'Utilities', 'LotConfig',
       'LandSlope', 'Neighborhood', 'Condition1', 'Condition2', 'BldgType',
       'HouseStyle', 'OverallQual', 'OverallCond', 'YearBuilt', 'YearRemodAdd',
       'RoofStyle', 'RoofMatl', 'Exterior1st', 'Exterior2nd', 'MasVnrType',
       'MasVnrArea', 'ExterQual', 'ExterCond', 'Foundation', 'BsmtQual',
       'BsmtCond', 'BsmtExposure', 'BsmtFinType1', 'BsmtFinSF1',
       'BsmtFinType2', 'BsmtFinSF2', 'BsmtUnfSF', 'TotalBsmtSF', 'Heating',
       'HeatingQC', 'CentralAir', 'Electrical', '1stFlrSF', '2ndFlrSF',
       'LowQualFinSF', 'GrLivArea', 'BsmtFullBath', 'BsmtHalfBath', 'FullBath',
       'HalfBath', 'BedroomAbvGr', 'KitchenAbvGr', 'KitchenQual',
       'TotRmsAbvGrd', 'Functional', 'Fireplaces', 'FireplaceQu', 'GarageType',
       'GarageYrBlt', 'GarageFinish', 'GarageCars', 'GarageArea', 'GarageQual',
       'GarageCond', 'PavedDrive', 'WoodDeckSF', 'OpenPorchSF',
       'EnclosedPorch', '3SsnPorch', 'ScreenPorch', 'PoolArea', 'PoolQC',
       'Fence', 'MiscFeature', 'MiscVal', 'MoSold', 'YrSold', 'SaleType',
       'SaleCondition', 'SalePrice'],
      dtype='object')

Generate few first rows

df.head()

Id MSSubClass MSZoning LotFrontage LotArea Street Alley LotShape LandContour Utilities ... PoolArea PoolQC Fence MiscFeature MiscVal MoSold YrSold SaleType SaleCondition SalePrice
0 1 60 RL 65.0 8450 Pave NaN Reg Lvl AllPub ... 0 NaN NaN NaN 0 2 2008 WD Normal 208500
1 2 20 RL 80.0 9600 Pave NaN Reg Lvl AllPub ... 0 NaN NaN NaN 0 5 2007 WD Normal 181500
2 3 60 RL 68.0 11250 Pave NaN IR1 Lvl AllPub ... 0 NaN NaN NaN 0 9 2008 WD Normal 223500
3 4 70 RL 60.0 9550 Pave NaN IR1 Lvl AllPub ... 0 NaN NaN NaN 0 2 2006 WD Abnorml 140000
4 5 60 RL 84.0 14260 Pave NaN IR1 Lvl AllPub ... 0 NaN NaN NaN 0 12 2008 WD Normal 250000

5 rows × 81 columns

Missing vals count in each column

df.isnull().sum().sort_values(ascending=False).head(20)

PoolQC          1453
MiscFeature     1406
Alley           1369
Fence           1179
FireplaceQu      690
LotFrontage      259
GarageCond        81
GarageType        81
GarageYrBlt       81
GarageFinish      81
GarageQual        81
BsmtExposure      38
BsmtFinType2      38
BsmtFinType1      37
BsmtCond          37
BsmtQual          37
MasVnrArea         8
MasVnrType         8
Electrical         1
Utilities          0
dtype: int64

Generate Columns that have more than 20 percent missing vals

threshold_20 = (df.isnull().sum()/df.shape[0]*100)
threshold_20[threshold_20>20].sort_values(ascending=False)

PoolQC         99.520548
MiscFeature    96.301370
Alley          93.767123
Fence          80.753425
FireplaceQu    47.260274
dtype: float64

df.dtypes.value_counts()

object     43
int64      35
float64     3
dtype: int64

Drop cols with more than 20 percent missing vals

cols_to_drop = threshold_20[threshold_20>20].index.to_list()
df.drop(cols_to_drop, inplace=True, axis=1)

Also drop Id, this would not have been necessary if this was set as index column when data was first read

df.drop(['Id'], inplace=True, axis=1)

Categorical features and numeric features

categorical_features = df.select_dtypes(include="object").columns.to_list()

What were the columns?

# MiscFeature: Miscellaneous feature not covered in other categories
# PoolQC: Pool quality
# Alley: Type of alley access to property
# Fence: Fence quality
# FireplaceQu: Fireplace quality

print ('Categorical Features')
print (categorical_features)

Categorical Features
['MSZoning', 'Street', 'LotShape', 'LandContour', 'Utilities', 'LotConfig', 'LandSlope', 'Neighborhood', 'Condition1', 'Condition2', 'BldgType', 'HouseStyle', 'RoofStyle', 'RoofMatl', 'Exterior1st', 'Exterior2nd', 'MasVnrType', 'ExterQual', 'ExterCond', 'Foundation', 'BsmtQual', 'BsmtCond', 'BsmtExposure', 'BsmtFinType1', 'BsmtFinType2', 'Heating', 'HeatingQC', 'CentralAir', 'Electrical', 'KitchenQual', 'Functional', 'GarageType', 'GarageFinish', 'GarageQual', 'GarageCond', 'PavedDrive', 'SaleType', 'SaleCondition']

Cardinality

df[categorical_features].nunique()

MSZoning          5
Street            2
LotShape          4
LandContour       4
Utilities         2
LotConfig         5
LandSlope         3
Neighborhood     25
Condition1        9
Condition2        8
BldgType          5
HouseStyle        8
RoofStyle         6
RoofMatl          8
Exterior1st      15
Exterior2nd      16
MasVnrType        4
ExterQual         4
ExterCond         5
Foundation        6
BsmtQual          4
BsmtCond          4
BsmtExposure      4
BsmtFinType1      6
BsmtFinType2      6
Heating           6
HeatingQC         5
CentralAir        2
Electrical        5
KitchenQual       4
Functional        7
GarageType        6
GarageFinish      3
GarageQual        5
GarageCond        5
PavedDrive        3
SaleType          9
SaleCondition     6
dtype: int64

Baseline model

X = df.iloc[:, :-1]
y = df['SalePrice']

X_train_, X_val_, y_train, y_val = train_test_split(X, y, test_size = .2, random_state = 6174)


# Columns that can be safely label encoded
# This will still be an issue in production since 
# some of the encodings will fail
good_label_cols = [col for col in categorical_features if 
                   set(X_train_[col]) == set(X_val_[col])]

# Problematic columns that will be dropped from the dataset
bad_label_cols = list(set(categorical_features) - set(good_label_cols))

X_train = X_train_.copy()
X_val = X_val_.copy()

# Drop categorical columns that will not be encoded
X_train.drop(bad_label_cols, axis=1, inplace=True)
X_val.drop(bad_label_cols, axis=1, inplace=True)


# Works here but there might be instances where datetime might be here as well
numeric_features = X.select_dtypes(exclude="object").columns.to_list()

numerical_imputer = SimpleImputer(strategy='median')
X_train[numeric_features] = numerical_imputer.fit_transform(X_train[numeric_features])
X_val[numeric_features] = numerical_imputer.transform(X_val[numeric_features])

category_imputer = SimpleImputer(strategy='most_frequent')
X_train[good_label_cols] = category_imputer.fit_transform(X_train[good_label_cols])
X_val[good_label_cols] = category_imputer.fit_transform(X_val[good_label_cols])

label_encoder = LabelEncoder()
for col in good_label_cols:
    X_train[col] = label_encoder.fit_transform(X_train[col])
    X_val[col] = label_encoder.transform(X_val[col])

RandomForestRegressor as our baseline model

model = RandomForestRegressor(n_estimators=100, random_state=6174)
model.fit(X_train, y_train)
preds = model.predict(X_val)

Calculate MAE

score = mean_absolute_error(y_val, preds)
print('MAE RandomForestRegressor:', score)

MAE RandomForestRegressor: 16926.070136986298

Test XGBRegressor

model2 = XGBRegressor(n_estimators=1000, learning_rate=0.05, n_jobs=4)
model2.fit(X_train, y_train, 
             early_stopping_rounds=2, 
             eval_set=[(X_val, y_val)], 
             verbose=False)
preds2 = model2.predict(X_val)

[13:44:57] WARNING: src/objective/regression_obj.cu:152: reg:linear is now deprecated in favor of reg:squarederror.

Calculate MAE

score2 = mean_absolute_error(y_val, preds2)
print('MAE XGBoost:', score2)

MAE XGBoost: 17124.455559717466

Looking at the leaderboard, this is not a good score. But, this model is useful because now we can look into ways to impove it.

Updating model with pipeline (and a bit of improvement in between)

Imports

import numpy as np 
import pandas as pd 
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestRegressor
from xgboost import XGBRegressor
from sklearn.model_selection import cross_val_score
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
from sklearn.compose import ColumnTransformer
from sklearn.pipeline import Pipeline
from sklearn.impute import SimpleImputer
from sklearn.preprocessing import OneHotEncoder
from sklearn.metrics import mean_absolute_error

Read the training dataset and list its shape and column names

df = pd.read_csv('../data/AmesHousing/train.csv', index_col='Id')
print (df.shape)
print (df.columns)

(1460, 80)
Index(['MSSubClass', 'MSZoning', 'LotFrontage', 'LotArea', 'Street', 'Alley',
       'LotShape', 'LandContour', 'Utilities', 'LotConfig', 'LandSlope',
       'Neighborhood', 'Condition1', 'Condition2', 'BldgType', 'HouseStyle',
       'OverallQual', 'OverallCond', 'YearBuilt', 'YearRemodAdd', 'RoofStyle',
       'RoofMatl', 'Exterior1st', 'Exterior2nd', 'MasVnrType', 'MasVnrArea',
       'ExterQual', 'ExterCond', 'Foundation', 'BsmtQual', 'BsmtCond',
       'BsmtExposure', 'BsmtFinType1', 'BsmtFinSF1', 'BsmtFinType2',
       'BsmtFinSF2', 'BsmtUnfSF', 'TotalBsmtSF', 'Heating', 'HeatingQC',
       'CentralAir', 'Electrical', '1stFlrSF', '2ndFlrSF', 'LowQualFinSF',
       'GrLivArea', 'BsmtFullBath', 'BsmtHalfBath', 'FullBath', 'HalfBath',
       'BedroomAbvGr', 'KitchenAbvGr', 'KitchenQual', 'TotRmsAbvGrd',
       'Functional', 'Fireplaces', 'FireplaceQu', 'GarageType', 'GarageYrBlt',
       'GarageFinish', 'GarageCars', 'GarageArea', 'GarageQual', 'GarageCond',
       'PavedDrive', 'WoodDeckSF', 'OpenPorchSF', 'EnclosedPorch', '3SsnPorch',
       'ScreenPorch', 'PoolArea', 'PoolQC', 'Fence', 'MiscFeature', 'MiscVal',
       'MoSold', 'YrSold', 'SaleType', 'SaleCondition', 'SalePrice'],
      dtype='object')

Generate few first rows

df.head()

MSSubClass MSZoning LotFrontage LotArea Street Alley LotShape LandContour Utilities LotConfig ... PoolArea PoolQC Fence MiscFeature MiscVal MoSold YrSold SaleType SaleCondition SalePrice
Id
1 60 RL 65.0 8450 Pave NaN Reg Lvl AllPub Inside ... 0 NaN NaN NaN 0 2 2008 WD Normal 208500
2 20 RL 80.0 9600 Pave NaN Reg Lvl AllPub FR2 ... 0 NaN NaN NaN 0 5 2007 WD Normal 181500
3 60 RL 68.0 11250 Pave NaN IR1 Lvl AllPub Inside ... 0 NaN NaN NaN 0 9 2008 WD Normal 223500
4 70 RL 60.0 9550 Pave NaN IR1 Lvl AllPub Corner ... 0 NaN NaN NaN 0 2 2006 WD Abnorml 140000
5 60 RL 84.0 14260 Pave NaN IR1 Lvl AllPub FR2 ... 0 NaN NaN NaN 0 12 2008 WD Normal 250000

5 rows × 80 columns

Missing vals count in each column

df.isnull().sum().sort_values(ascending=False).head(20)

PoolQC          1453
MiscFeature     1406
Alley           1369
Fence           1179
FireplaceQu      690
LotFrontage      259
GarageType        81
GarageCond        81
GarageFinish      81
GarageQual        81
GarageYrBlt       81
BsmtFinType2      38
BsmtExposure      38
BsmtQual          37
BsmtCond          37
BsmtFinType1      37
MasVnrArea         8
MasVnrType         8
Electrical         1
RoofMatl           0
dtype: int64

Generate Columns that have more than 20 percent missing vals

threshold_20 = (df.isnull().sum()/df.shape[0]*100)
threshold_20[threshold_20>20].sort_values(ascending=False)

PoolQC         99.520548
MiscFeature    96.301370
Alley          93.767123
Fence          80.753425
FireplaceQu    47.260274
dtype: float64

df.dtypes.value_counts()

object     43
int64      34
float64     3
dtype: int64

Drop cols with more than 20 percent missing vals

cols_to_drop = threshold_20[threshold_20>20].index.to_list()
df.drop(cols_to_drop, inplace=True, axis=1)

Categorical features and numeric features

categorical_features = df.select_dtypes(include="object").columns.to_list()

What were the columns?



# MiscFeature: Miscellaneous feature not covered in other categories
# PoolQC: Pool quality
# Alley: Type of alley access to property
# Fence: Fence quality
# FireplaceQu: Fireplace quality

print ('Categorical Features')
print (categorical_features)

Categorical Features
['MSZoning', 'Street', 'LotShape', 'LandContour', 'Utilities', 'LotConfig', 'LandSlope', 'Neighborhood', 'Condition1', 'Condition2', 'BldgType', 'HouseStyle', 'RoofStyle', 'RoofMatl', 'Exterior1st', 'Exterior2nd', 'MasVnrType', 'ExterQual', 'ExterCond', 'Foundation', 'BsmtQual', 'BsmtCond', 'BsmtExposure', 'BsmtFinType1', 'BsmtFinType2', 'Heating', 'HeatingQC', 'CentralAir', 'Electrical', 'KitchenQual', 'Functional', 'GarageType', 'GarageFinish', 'GarageQual', 'GarageCond', 'PavedDrive', 'SaleType', 'SaleCondition']

Cardinality

df[categorical_features].nunique()

MSZoning          5
Street            2
LotShape          4
LandContour       4
Utilities         2
LotConfig         5
LandSlope         3
Neighborhood     25
Condition1        9
Condition2        8
BldgType          5
HouseStyle        8
RoofStyle         6
RoofMatl          8
Exterior1st      15
Exterior2nd      16
MasVnrType        4
ExterQual         4
ExterCond         5
Foundation        6
BsmtQual          4
BsmtCond          4
BsmtExposure      4
BsmtFinType1      6
BsmtFinType2      6
Heating           6
HeatingQC         5
CentralAir        2
Electrical        5
KitchenQual       4
Functional        7
GarageType        6
GarageFinish      3
GarageQual        5
GarageCond        5
PavedDrive        3
SaleType          9
SaleCondition     6
dtype: int64

Baseline model with pipelines and OneHotEncoder

X = df.iloc[:, :-1]
y = df['SalePrice']

X_train_, X_val_, y_train, y_val = train_test_split(X, y, test_size = .2, random_state = 6174)


# Columns that can be safely label encoded
# This will still be an issue in production since 
# some of the encodings will fail
good_label_cols = [col for col in categorical_features if 
                   set(X_train_[col]) == set(X_val_[col])]
                    
# Problematic columns that will be dropped from the dataset
bad_label_cols = list(set(categorical_features) - set(good_label_cols))

X_train = X_train_.copy()
X_val = X_val_.copy()

Pipepline

# pipeline

numeric_features = X_train.select_dtypes(exclude="object").columns.to_list()
numerical_transformer = SimpleImputer(strategy='median')

# Preprocessing for categorical data
categorical_transformer = Pipeline(steps=[
    ('imputer', SimpleImputer(strategy='most_frequent')),
    ('onehot', OneHotEncoder(handle_unknown='ignore'))
])

# Bundle preprocessing for numerical and categorical data
preprocessor = ColumnTransformer(
    transformers=[
        ('num', numerical_transformer, numeric_features),
        ('cat', categorical_transformer, good_label_cols)
    ])

RandomForestRegressor as our baseline model

model = RandomForestRegressor(n_estimators=100, random_state=6174)

#### Complete Pipeline

my_pipeline = Pipeline(steps=[('preprocessor', preprocessor),
                              ('model', model)
                             ])

my_pipeline.fit(X_train, y_train)

Pipeline(memory=None,
         steps=[('preprocessor',
                 ColumnTransformer(n_jobs=None, remainder='drop',
                                   sparse_threshold=0.3,
                                   transformer_weights=None,
                                   transformers=[('num',
                                                  SimpleImputer(add_indicator=False,
                                                                copy=True,
                                                                fill_value=None,
                                                                missing_values=nan,
                                                                strategy='median',
                                                                verbose=0),
                                                  ['MSSubClass', 'LotFrontage',
                                                   'LotArea', 'OverallQual',
                                                   'OverallCond', 'YearBuilt',
                                                   'YearR...
                 RandomForestRegressor(bootstrap=True, ccp_alpha=0.0,
                                       criterion='mse', max_depth=None,
                                       max_features='auto', max_leaf_nodes=None,
                                       max_samples=None,
                                       min_impurity_decrease=0.0,
                                       min_impurity_split=None,
                                       min_samples_leaf=1, min_samples_split=2,
                                       min_weight_fraction_leaf=0.0,
                                       n_estimators=100, n_jobs=None,
                                       oob_score=False, random_state=6174,
                                       verbose=0, warm_start=False))],
         verbose=False)

Calculate MAE

preds = my_pipeline.predict(X_val)
score = mean_absolute_error(y_val, preds)
print('MAE:', score)

MAE: 16905.403253424658

EDA to improve the model further

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
sns.axes_style("darkgrid")
from xgboost import XGBRegressor

from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestRegressor
from sklearn.model_selection import cross_val_score
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
from sklearn.compose import ColumnTransformer
from sklearn.pipeline import Pipeline
from sklearn.impute import SimpleImputer
from sklearn.preprocessing import OneHotEncoder
from sklearn.metrics import mean_absolute_error
from sklearn.model_selection import cross_val_score

df = pd.read_csv('../data/AmesHousing/train.csv', index_col='Id')
print (df.shape)
print (df.columns)

(1460, 80)
Index(['MSSubClass', 'MSZoning', 'LotFrontage', 'LotArea', 'Street', 'Alley',
       'LotShape', 'LandContour', 'Utilities', 'LotConfig', 'LandSlope',
       'Neighborhood', 'Condition1', 'Condition2', 'BldgType', 'HouseStyle',
       'OverallQual', 'OverallCond', 'YearBuilt', 'YearRemodAdd', 'RoofStyle',
       'RoofMatl', 'Exterior1st', 'Exterior2nd', 'MasVnrType', 'MasVnrArea',
       'ExterQual', 'ExterCond', 'Foundation', 'BsmtQual', 'BsmtCond',
       'BsmtExposure', 'BsmtFinType1', 'BsmtFinSF1', 'BsmtFinType2',
       'BsmtFinSF2', 'BsmtUnfSF', 'TotalBsmtSF', 'Heating', 'HeatingQC',
       'CentralAir', 'Electrical', '1stFlrSF', '2ndFlrSF', 'LowQualFinSF',
       'GrLivArea', 'BsmtFullBath', 'BsmtHalfBath', 'FullBath', 'HalfBath',
       'BedroomAbvGr', 'KitchenAbvGr', 'KitchenQual', 'TotRmsAbvGrd',
       'Functional', 'Fireplaces', 'FireplaceQu', 'GarageType', 'GarageYrBlt',
       'GarageFinish', 'GarageCars', 'GarageArea', 'GarageQual', 'GarageCond',
       'PavedDrive', 'WoodDeckSF', 'OpenPorchSF', 'EnclosedPorch', '3SsnPorch',
       'ScreenPorch', 'PoolArea', 'PoolQC', 'Fence', 'MiscFeature', 'MiscVal',
       'MoSold', 'YrSold', 'SaleType', 'SaleCondition', 'SalePrice'],
      dtype='object')

X, y = df.iloc[:, :-1], df['SalePrice']
y = np.log(y)

y

Understanding Data

Missing vals

df.isnull().sum().sort_values(ascending=False)

PoolQC           1453
MiscFeature      1406
Alley            1369
Fence            1179
FireplaceQu       690
                 ... 
CentralAir          0
SaleCondition       0
Heating             0

MSSubClass          0
Length: 80, dtype: int64

na_per = (df.isnull().sum()/df.shape[0]*100).sort_values(ascending=False).head(20)
na_per

PoolQC          99.520548
MiscFeature     96.301370
Alley           93.767123
Fence           80.753425
FireplaceQu     47.260274
LotFrontage     17.739726
GarageType       5.547945
GarageCond       5.547945
GarageFinish     5.547945
GarageQual       5.547945
GarageYrBlt      5.547945
BsmtFinType2     2.602740
BsmtExposure     2.602740
BsmtQual         2.534247
BsmtCond         2.534247
BsmtFinType1     2.534247

dtype: float64

high_missing_features = na_per[na_per>20].index.to_list()

high_missing_features

['PoolQC', 'MiscFeature', 'Alley', 'Fence', 'FireplaceQu']

Data Types

df.dtypes.value_counts()

object     43
int64      34
float64     3
dtype: int64

Categorical Features

categorical_features = list(df.select_dtypes(include = ['object']))
print (categorical_features)

['MSZoning', 'Street', 'Alley', 'LotShape', 'LandContour', 'Utilities', 'LotConfig', 'LandSlope', 'Neighborhood', 'Condition1', 'Condition2', 'BldgType', 'HouseStyle', 'RoofStyle', 'RoofMatl', 'Exterior1st', 'Exterior2nd', 'MasVnrType', 'ExterQual', 'ExterCond', 'Foundation', 'BsmtQual', 'BsmtCond', 'BsmtExposure', 'BsmtFinType1', 'BsmtFinType2', 'Heating', 'HeatingQC', 'CentralAir', 'Electrical', 'KitchenQual', 'Functional', 'FireplaceQu', 'GarageType', 'GarageFinish', 'GarageQual', 'GarageCond', 'PavedDrive', 'PoolQC', 'Fence', 'MiscFeature', 'SaleType', 'SaleCondition']

fig = plt.figure(figsize=(18, 40))
for index, col in enumerate(categorical_features):
    plt.subplot(len(categorical_features)//4 +1 , 4, index+1)
    sns.countplot(x = col, data = X)
fig.tight_layout(pad=1.0)

Missing vals

plt.close(fig)
fig = plt.figure(figsize=(18, 40))
for index, col in enumerate(categorical_features):
    plt.subplot(len(categorical_features)//3 +1 , 3, index+1)
    sns.boxplot(x=col, y="SalePrice", data=df);
fig.tight_layout(pad=1.0)

Findings

  1. Remove [“Street”, “Utilities”, “RoofMatl”, “Heating”, “Condition2”]
  2. There are some categorical features that are ordinal in nature. What can be done regarding that?
  3. Add MSSubClass from numeric to categorical feature

Numerical Features

numerical_features = list(X.select_dtypes(exclude = ['object']))
numerical_features.remove('MSSubClass')
categorical_features.append('MSSubClass')
print (numerical_features)

['LotFrontage', 'LotArea', 'OverallQual', 'OverallCond', 'YearBuilt', 'YearRemodAdd', 'MasVnrArea', 'BsmtFinSF1', 'BsmtFinSF2', 'BsmtUnfSF', 'TotalBsmtSF', '1stFlrSF', '2ndFlrSF', 'LowQualFinSF', 'GrLivArea', 'BsmtFullBath', 'BsmtHalfBath', 'FullBath', 'HalfBath', 'BedroomAbvGr', 'KitchenAbvGr', 'TotRmsAbvGrd', 'Fireplaces', 'GarageYrBlt', 'GarageCars', 'GarageArea', 'WoodDeckSF', 'OpenPorchSF', 'EnclosedPorch', '3SsnPorch', 'ScreenPorch', 'PoolArea', 'MiscVal', 'MoSold', 'YrSold']

Findings

  1. Features to remove [“MiscVal”, “PoolArea”, “ScreenPorch”, “3SsnPorch”, “EnclosedPorch”, “BsmtHalfBath”, “LowQualityFinSF”, “BsmtFinSF2”]
plt.figure(figsize=(14,12))
correlation = X[numerical_features].corr()
sns.heatmap(correlation, mask = correlation < 0.8, linewidth=0.5, cmap='Blues')

<matplotlib.axes._subplots.AxesSubplot at 0x7fa33299e4d0>

Findings:

  1. Remove [“GarageYrBlt”, “TotalBsmtSF”, “TotRmsAbvGrd”, “GarageCars”]
# Features to remove:

remove_highly_correlated = ["GarageYrBlt", "TotRmsAbvGrd", "TotalBsmtSF", "GarageCars"]

remove_numeric = ["MiscVal", "PoolArea", "ScreenPorch", "3SsnPorch", "EnclosedPorch", "BsmtHalfBath", "LowQualFinSF", "BsmtFinSF2"]

remove_categorical = ["Street", "Utilities", "RoofMatl", "Heating", "Condition2"] 

remove_features =  list(set(remove_highly_correlated+remove_numeric+remove_categorical))

remove_features

The findings can be encorporated to the model (remove features, engineer features, remove outliers etc.) to improve the model. This part is left the the students.
